Fig. 3 SEM morphological characterizations of as-synthesized material in the different magnification. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) TEM photograph of as-synthesized material, (c) high resolution lattice image, showing well-defined nano-crystalline regions, and (d) electron diffraction pattern. Fig. 5 Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms of 3D macro-/nanoporous Co3O4 with corresponding pore-size distribution (inset) calculated by BJH method from desorption. Fig. 6 CO conversion and O2 selectively to CO2over 3D macro-/nanoporous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles catalyst, respectively. Fig. 7 Time-on-stream CO conversion on 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 at 140°C and Co3O4 nanoparticles at 183°C, respectively. Fig. 8 High-resolution XPS spectra for scans of the Co 2p (a) and (b) region and the O 1s (c) and (d) region for 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. Structure and catalytic activity of 3D macro/mesoporous Co3O4 for CO oxidation prepared by a facile self-sustained decomposition of metal–organic complexes Shaojuan Deng a Xuechun Xiao a Xinxin Xing a Jinming Wu b Wei Wen b Yude Wang a ⁎ a Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Yunnan University, 650091 Kunming, PR China Department of Materials Science and Engineering Yunnan University Kunming 650091 PR China b State Key Lab of Silicon Materials, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China State Key Lab of Silicon Materials Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 871 65031124; fax: +86 871 65153832. Graphical abstract Three-dimensional macro/mesoporous tricobalt tetraoxide Co3O4 was prepared via a facile self-sustained decomposition using the complexes of metallic salts and organics (metal–organic complexes). Porous Co3O4 material was characterized using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) to examine the morphology and microstructure to find out the cause. Co3O4 with the 3D hierarchical porous structure consisting of nanoparticles has a coral-like shape with a size of tens of micrometers and exhibits the hierarchically porous morphology, in which the walls of the macropores contain smaller mesopores. The catalytic performance of the porous Co3O4 for CO oxidation has been studied with a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz microreactor. The porous Co3O4 exhibits excellent catalytic activity for CO oxidation, the CO conversion rate reaches 100% at 140°C. Keywords Flash synthesis Three-dimensional macro/mesoporous tricobalt tetraoxide Hierarchical porous structure Carbon monoxide oxidation 1 Introduction As an important p-type semiconductor and a promising functional material, cubic spinel-type tricobalt tetraoxide (Co3O4) has been widely applied in Li ion batteries [1,2], supercapacitors [3,4], sensors [5], heterogeneous catalysis [6,7], magnetic materials [8], and other applications due to its excellent redox activity and environmental friendliness [9]. The morphology and microstructure of Co3O4 material, including the particle size, defects, the properties of surface and interface, the barrier height/width, and stoichiometry, play a crucial role in the electrochemical performances and catalytic activities. Co3O4 is widely used as a non-noble metallic oxide in the catalysis field and shows very high CO oxidation activity in CO/O2 mixtures even at ambient temperature. Through increasing surface area, decreasing particle size distribution and preferentially exposing more active lattice planes, the catalytic performance of Co3O4 could be optimized [10]. Compared with conventional nanoparticulate system, porous Co3O4, possessing the advantages of large surface areas, distinctive structural features, and intriguing properties, has attracted much attention in catalysis [11,12]. It has been shown that porous Co3O4 exhibited much better catalytic performance than bulk Co3O4 in CO oxidation [13,14]. The synthesis and preparation of porous Co3O4 with desired structure and morphology are of great technological and scientific interests owing to their superior electrochemical performances and catalytic activities. Many efforts have been focused to prepare porous Co3O4 with high surface area values by different methods. Indeed it is expected that the hierarchical porous sizes in the micro- or nano-regime and specific crystal morphologies could enhance the performance. Up to now, most approaches to porous materials focus on template-assisted processes, including hard templates (porous silicon and polystyrene sphere) and soft templates (surfactants, block copolymers). For example, Che et al. reported porous Co3O4 microdiscs prepared via a facile thermal decomposition [15]. Polycrystalline mesoporous Co3O4 has been successfully fabricated using a simple but efficient controlled thermal decomposition approach [10]. Tüysüz et al. prepared cubic ordered mesoporous Co3O4 via the nanocasting pathway using KIT-6 as hard template [16]. A hierarchically porous Co3O4 has been prepared by using hierarchically porous silica monoliths with a discontinuous pore structure at the micrometer length scale and 3.4nm surfactant templated mesopores as hard templates [17]. Although great progress has been made, it remains a challenge to synthesize porous Co3O4 with controlled morphology and pore size due to the fact that the performance of Co3O4 improved by designed porous structure and novel morphology is still undesirable [15]. Therefore, the development of new synthetic routes in order to obtain porous Co3O4 material is of a great significance. On the other hand, the porosity of the products prepared by the template-free route is relatively low and the preparation procedure is also multi-step and complex. Herein, we report a rapid and feasible template/surfactant-free route to fabricate a 3D macro-/mesoporous Co3O4, which possesses a coral-like shape with a size of tens of micrometers and the hierarchically porous morphology, in which the walls of the macropores contain smaller mesopores. The achieved 3D macro-/mesoporous Co3O4 was used as active catalyst for CO oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of 3D macro-/mesoporous Co3O4 All the reagents used in the experiments were purchased from commercial sources of analytical grade and used without further purification. The synthesis of 3D macro-/nanoporous Co3O4 was performed by rapidly heating aqueous solution contains stoichiometric quantity of corresponding metal nitrates and acetates, hydrazine monohydrate (N2H4·H2O), and glycine (C2H5NO2) at a certain temperature (400°C). Scheme 1 illustrates the synthesis procedure of porous Co3O4. In a typical synthesis, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, N2H4·H2O, and glycine with a molar ratio (Co2+:C2H5NO2:N2H4·H2O=2:1:2) were dissolved in deionized water (20ml) to form a turbid precursor of metal–organic complex. After magnetically stirring for 10min, the mixture was poured into a crucible and transferred to a preheated furnace at 400°C. After the elapsed reaction time of 30min, the crucible was taken out from the furnace and left to cool down spontaneously to the room temperature. The resultant powders were collected and directly subjected to the various characterizations. For comparison of CO oxidation reaction, we also prepared Co3O4 nanoparticles using Co(NO3)2·6H2O by a thermal decomposition method at 400°C. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were carried out by Rigaku D/max-3B diffractometer with an incident X-ray wavelength of 1.540Å (CuKα line), operated at 40kV, 100mA. The sample was scanned from 10° to 90° (2θ) in steps of 0.01°. The crystallite domain sizes (D) have been examined from XRD peaks based on the Scherrer’s equation: D =0.9λ/(ΔWcosθ), where λ is the wavelength of X-ray (λ =0.15418nm), θ is the Bragg’s diffraction angle, and ΔW is the true half-peak width of the X-ray diffraction lines. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the morphology of porous materials were obtained from FEI QUANTA200 with microscope operating at 30kV. The samples for SEM were prepared by dispersing the final powders in the conductive glue; this dispersing was then sprayed with gold. Detailed studies of the microstructure were also carried out by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL JEM-2100) at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw InVia Raman microscope, equipped with a CCD (charge coupled device) with the detector cooled to about 153K using liquid N2. XPS spectra were acquired on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with monochromatic Al-Kα X-ray source (power: 250W). The electron take-off angle to the sample surface was adjusted to 45°. The adventitious hydrocarbon C1s signal at 284.6eV was used as the energy reference to correct for charging. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K were recorded on a Micromeritics AutoPore IV 9500 system. The samples were outgassed 20h at 150°C before the analysis. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The porous Co3O4 catalyst with 50mg was packed into a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz microreactor. The catalyst was placed in the bottom of one side of a U-shaped microreactor without any pressing. The CO catalytic activity was evaluated under an atmosphere pressure flow of 30Lh−1 g−1, in a gas mixture of 1vol% CO in air (1vol% CO, 19.8vol% O2, balanced with nitrogen). The catalyst was heated to the desired reaction temperature at a rate of 2°Cmin−1 and then kept there for 50min until the catalytic reaction reached a steady state. The composition of effluent was monitored for CO and CO2 concentration by GC 9800. The CO conversion (R CO) and O2 conversion ( R O 2 ) were calculated from the change in CO and O2 concentrations of the inlet and outlet gases as follows: (1) R CO = ( 1 − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in ) × 100 % (2) R O 2 = ( 1 − [ O ] out [ O ] in ) × 100 % where [CO]in and [CO]out, [O]in and [O]out stand for the CO and O2 concentrations in the feed gas and effluent gas, respectively. CO2 selectivity (β, O2 selectivity to CO2) in the presence of hydrogen (1.0% CO, 2.0% O2, 97.0% H2, balance with nitrogen, space velocity: 30Lh−1 g−1) was calculated on the basis of the equation as follow: (3) β = R CO 2 × R O 2 × 100 % 3 Results and discussion The crystallinity and phase structure of the as-prepared material was determined by X-ray diffraction studies. As shown in Fig. 1 , the XRD pattern of the final black powders exhibits the well-developed Bragg diffraction peaks of typical cubic system and polycrystalline nature, which is in good accordance with the result of JCPDS No. 42-1467. The diffraction peaks at 18.96°, 31.24°, 36.86°, 38.61°, 44.76°, 55.67°, 59.32°, and 65.18° can be, respectively, denoted as (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), and (440) reflections. The hkl indexes indicated in the plot correspond to the Co3O4 spinel structure. No other phase peaks observed demonstrates that the cobalt source was transformed into Co3O4 completely after combustion synthesis at 400°C. The application of Scherrer’s equation to the (311) plane diffraction peak (2θ =36.86°) of the XRD spectrum yields a crystal size of ∼30nm. Co3O4 nanoparticles showed the same cubic spinel phase (Fig. S1 in Supplementary data) with a crystal size of ∼28nm.The formation of a cubic structure in the as-synthesized porous Co3O4 was further supported by Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 2 exhibits the typical Raman-scattering spectrum of the porous Co3O4, at an excitation wavelength of 532nm at ambient temperature. The acquired spectrum shows the appearance of the modes as predicted by group theory for Co3O4 (space group Fd 3 ¯ m (227)), having the 5 Raman bands with strong and broadening peaks. The peaks at 192, 515, and 610cm−1 can be attributed to F2g modes, at 190cm−1 to F2g mode, and at 665cm−1 to A1g mode, respectively. The peak positions are in agreement with those reported for crystalline Co3O4 [18,19], except some of peaks are shifted several cm−1. The band at the position 665cm−1 (A1g) signals the octahedral site and the band at 190cm−1 (F2g) signals the tetrahedral site [20]. Broad nature of the peaks with low intensity indicates the formation of nanocrystalline Co3O4. The Raman spectra are thus in good accordance with the XRD result. The morphology of as-prepared material was characterized by SEM and shown in Fig. 3 . The as-synthesized powder shows a coral-like shaped particle at low magnification (Fig. 3(a) and (b)). The coral-like shaped particles with a size of tens of micrometers are consisted of interconnected spherical particles forming a 3D hierarchical porous structure with typical bimodal porous morphology, in which the walls of the macropores contain smaller mesopores. The Co3O4 nanoparticles were irregular particle with uniform particle size distribution (Fig. S2 in Supplementary data). TEM investigations give further insight into the morphology and the structural features of the as-synthesized material. TEM image (Fig. 4 (a)) clearly shows that the 3D hierarchical architecture consisting of nanoparticles, the mesopores are formed by the aggregation of nanoparticles and the macropores are self-assembled by nanoparticles, which further confirms SEM deduction. The wall thickness of the macropores is ca. 300nm and the walls consist of many fine nanoparticles (Fig. 4(b)). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of porous Co3O4 are shown in Fig. 4(c) and (d). The lattice spacing between adjacent planes measured from the observed lattice fringes of HRTEM image (Fig. 4(c)) is 0.470nm, corresponding to the distance between (111) crystal planes of cubic spinel Co3O4 phase. From Fig. 4(c), the small particles making up the hierarchically porous structure have a diameter in the range of 25–35nm, which is in good agreement with the average particle size obtained from XRD result. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 4(d)) demonstrates that the product is well crystallized Co3O4, which is consistent with the XRD result. The porous property of the resulting cobalt oxide was further investigated by measuring adsorption–desorption isotherms of nitrogen at 77K, as shown in Fig. 5 . Nitrogen sorption illustrates that nitrogen uptake takes place gradually across the entire adsorption branch of the isotherm indicative of a broad mesopore distribution. Significant hysteresis can be observed between the adsorption and desorption branches followed by the sharp forced closure of the desorption branch, near 0.45 P/P0, which suggests partial pore blocking. This means that the single nanoparticles within the 3D hierarchical porous structure are not really glued together (already observed in TEM), but are accessible from the outside via a secondary mesopore system. The pore size distribution (Fig. 5, inset) shows two small peaks at ca. 2.8 and 4.4nm, and one broad peak ranging from 5nm up to 30nm with a maximum at 7.2nm, indicating that the 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 possessed a trinal mesoporous structure. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of the 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 is ca. 24.85m2 g−1. The total pore volume is determined to be 0.105cm3 g−1. The specific surface area from BET measurement (Fig. S3 in Supplementary data) is approximately 18.6m2/g for Co3O4 nanoparticles. On the basis of the XRD, SEM, and TEM results, a possible growth mechanism during the combustion can be speculated. It is well-established that Co2+ can be complexed by N2H4·H2O, which further precipitates in the presence of anions such as CH3COO− [21,22]. As an oxidizer, NO3 − can react with N2H4 ·H2O. And little glycine is used to induce a relatively intensive combustion reaction. More importantly, the gas evolution from the decomposition of CH3COO− during the combustion results in the formation of the porous structure. In the present synthesis process, pores form simultaneously with the Co3O4 lattice formation in one-pot, eliminating the multi-steps of preparation and removal of templates in the commonly used template-assisted approaches. Therefore, the present synthesis route for porous materials is very simple and rapid. A similar process has been reported to generate macro-/mesoporous ZnO [23]. The catalytic performances of 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 were investigated by means of the CO oxidation reaction. The results obtained for the porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . As shown in Fig. 6, the porous Co3O4 catalyst exhibits excellent CO oxidation catalytic activity. As one can see, CO oxidation starts at 25°C and the value of the temperature which gives a 10% CO conversion is ca. 32°C, and the temperature of half conversion of CO (T 50) is about 73°C. On the porous Co3O4 catalyst, full conversion of CO, is reached at temperatures greater than 140°C. The result is also better than those of reported porous Co3O4 materials [6,14]. More interesting is that the CO oxidation activity of porous Co3O4 catalyst is significantly enhanced compared to that of Co3O4 nanoparticles due to the lower conversion temperature and higher conversion efficiency. Examining the O2 selectivity to CO2 in Fig. 6 shows that the 3D macro-/nanoporous Co3O4 is highly selectivity (>90%) when the temperature was at 100°C or below. A complete CO conversion with 87% selectivity was achieved at around 120°C. As temperature was raised to 150°C and higher, a clear drop in selectivity was observed. This results show that the 3D macro-/nanoporous Co3O4 has a highly selectivity to CO and this material might also be exploited for practical application in gas sensors. The stability of the 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 catalyst is examined under the same reaction conditions: 1vol% CO in air and atmosphere pressure flow of 30Lh−1 g−1. As shown in Fig. 7 , the porous Co3O4 catalyst undergoes slight deactivation during 20h on stream. The conversion of CO experiences deactivation of 10% and 16% for the 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. It has been attributed to the reduction of CoOx to lower valency states [24]. Surface compositions and chemical states of the as-synthesized 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 catalyst was carried out by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to further investigate the mechanism of CO oxidation. Apart from the C1s peak positioned at 284.0eV, which originated from spurious amounts of surface carbon of the decomposed glycine adsorbed onto the inorganic framework of porous Co3O4, XPS spectrum confirmed the high chemical purity of the Co3O4, consisting solely of Co and O. The typical spectra of Co 2p and O 1s binding energies are shown in Fig. 8 . From the Co 2p core level peaks (Fig. 8(a) and (b)), they are highly non-stoichiometric nature, suggesting that the Co atom in the as-prepared porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles catalysts has two valence states (tetrahedral Co2+ and octahedral Co3+ contributing to 2p spectral profile). They can be seen that main peaks of Co3+ 2p3/2 and Co3+ 2p1/2 are shown at binding energies of ∼779.1 and ∼794.1eV, respectively. The energy difference between the Co 2p3/2 peak and the Co 2p1/2 peak is approximately 15eV [25]. Those of Co2+ 2p3/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2 are located at ∼781.1 and ∼795.7eV. These spectra are fully consistent with those reported previously [10,25]. From Fig. 8(a) and (b), the ratios of Co3+/Ce2+ are 1.54 and 0.69 for 3D porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. It is obvious that 3D porous Co3O4 shows an increased ratio of Co3+/Co2+. Fig. 8(c) and (d) shows the O 1s XPS spectra of the two catalysts. To rationalize XPS findings, one can state that the Co3+ in the octahedral coordination of the Co3O4 spinel structure is the only favorable site for CO adsorption, as theoretically and experimentally confirmed in previous reports [26–28]. The O 1s peak can be fitted to two kinds of Gaussian peaks. The main peak at 529.7eV in the O 1s spectrum corresponds to oxygen ions in the crystal lattice (Olatt), while the line located at 531.4eV can be ascribed to the absorbed O x − ions (O− and O 2 − ions) in the oxygen deficient regions within the matrix of Co3O4 [6,25,29,30]. The ratio of oxygen vacancies to Olatt is 0.47 and 0.39 for 3D porous Co3O4 and Co3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. The ratio is obviously increased, indicating that the content of surface oxygen vacancy is increased by porous structure. The adsorbed oxygen species of O− and O 2 − are known to be active for oxygen exchange and CO oxidation [31–33]. Therefore, increasing the absorbed O x − ions contribute to the CO oxidation. The octahedral Co3+ and the absorbed O x − ions of the 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 surface may result in the high activity of the as-synthesized porous Co3O4. In this work, the mechanism of catalytic activity of Co3O4 for CO oxidation is accepted as an absorption and oxidation process of CO, which commonly takes place at surfaces of porous Co3O4 surface. It was proved that the exposed planes and position of Co3+ cations are suggested to be the major factors to determine the catalytic activity [34]. The oxygen vacancies are created by the absorbed O x − for charge balance, which greatly occupying the surface Co3+ sites leads to a large strain into the oxide lattice. Vacancies can also strongly bind reactants and assist in their dissociation. In the presence of CO and O2, CO is adsorbed on the surface-exposed Co3+ sites of Co3O4, and then the production of CO2 occurs by abstracting the surface oxygen that might be coordinated with three Co3+ cations. After that the resulting oxygen vacancy is subsequently filled by adsorption of O2 [35]. The role of cobalt(III) is to eliminate the negative charges efficiently from synergism effect, and be reduced to cobalt(II). Either lattice oxygen or dissociative dioxide absorbs at the surface reoxidates cobalt(II) to the original valence, and replenishes the surface vacancy to regenerate the lattice oxygen sites [36]. The redox cycle between Co3+ and Co2+ is largely responsible for CO oxidation [37]. Ultimately, the porous Co3O4 catalyst repeats absorption and oxidation of CO, then releases CO2 circularly. Hence, 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 with more surface Co3+ sites and absorbed O x − ions is favorable to improve the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, without use of any surfactant and template, 3D hierarchical porous Co3O4 with a coral-like shape was prepared via a facile self-sustained decomposition of metal–organic complexes. The obtained sample was systematically characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM, Raman, and N2 adsorption–desorption. The porous Co3O4 exhibits 3D hierarchical porous structure with typical bimodal porous morphology, in which the walls of the macropores contain smaller pores. It is suggested that this rapid and feasible template/surfactant-free route is an effective method to fabricate a 3D macro-/nanoporous oxides. The porous Co3O4 is very effective for the CO oxidation and the CO conversion rate reaches 100% at 140°C. It is worthwhile to note that the porous Co3O4 showed a much higher activity in CO oxidation than the Co3O4 nanoparticles, probably related to the facile redox nature of the octahedral Co3+ and the absorbed O x − ions of the porous structure. coredata.dc:description: Three-dimensional macro/mesoporous tricobalt tetraoxide Co3O4 was prepared via a facile self-sustained decomposition using the complexes of metallic salts and organics (metal–organic complexes). Porous Co3O4 material was characterized using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) to examine the morphology and microstructure to find out the cause. Co3O4 with the 3D hierarchical porous structure consisting of nanoparticles has a coral-like shape with a size of tens of micrometers and exhibits the hierarchically porous morphology, in which the walls of the macropores contain smaller mesopores. The catalytic performance of the porous Co3O4 for CO oxidation has been studied with a continuous flow fixed-bed quartz microreactor. The porous Co3O4 exhibits excellent catalytic activity for CO oxidation, the CO conversion rate reaches 100% at 140°C.
coredata.dc:title: Structure and catalytic activity of 3D macro/mesoporous Co3O4 for CO oxidation prepared by a facile self-sustained decomposition of metal–organic complexes
